name: IMANA
mission: IMANA fosters health promotion, disease prevention, and health maintenance in communities around the world through direct patient care, health programs,...
zakatClaimEvidence: IMANA explicitly lists "Zakat" as a donation option on its website. A dedicated page titled "Zakat Al Fitr Online Donation – IMANA" states, "The Zakat you entrust us with will be used for the direct support of IMANA's Medical Relief missions around the globe.". Furthermore, IMANA states, "IMANA collects and distributes zakat to those who are most in need, in accordance with Islamic guidelines." and "Donations made to IMANA Medical Relief are Zakat Eligible.". (Source: https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/grounding-api-redirect/AUZIYQEpH2I4gxJmhcgTj1QpYuTUur1VY2-opoACTcBpZcVN8VaxuTI9fliMtfA2qBSnuLV7Nkv1vmQ_txehzoYevoqalmURRj2bLC--tsNFuSmQONy_gCg=)

dimension_explanations.alignment: The organization shows high alignment for Muslim donors as a zakat-eligible entity addressing urgent global health crises [3]. Its mission focuses on health maintenance and disease prevention in underserved communities, matching high-priority humanitarian needs [1].
dimension_explanations.impact: IMANA demonstrates high effectiveness in direct service provision through programs like ServeRohingya and ServePakistan, maintaining a high data confidence level [1]. While the program expense ratio is 68.7%, the organization maintains a robust 33.0 months of working capital to ensure long-term stability [2].

The organization reported a total revenue of $2,874,345 and is recognized as a zakat-eligible entity for donors seeking to fulfill their religious obligations [2][3].

rich_narrative.amal_score_rationale: IMANA earns a strong overall standing due to its high accountability ratings and efficient fundraising, though its program expense ratio leaves some room for growth compared to its financial health scores.

areas_for_improvement.context: The organization has experienced a <cite id="15">3-year revenue CAGR of -21.3%</cite>, suggesting a need for more diversified or stable long-term funding streams.
While IMANA tracks <cite id="16">4 outcome metrics via Candid</cite>, it currently lacks a <cite id="17">documented theory of change</cite> to map long-term causal impact.

bbb_assessment.summary: The organization maintains high governance standards with audited financials and a fully independent board.

case_against.mitigation_notes: The organization's high liquidity of 31 months provides a buffer against revenue declines while they refine their impact reporting.
risk_factors: <cite id="17">Absence of a documented theory of change</cite>
case_against.summary: The primary concerns involve <cite id="15">declining revenue trends</cite> and a lack of <cite id="17">formalized impact evaluation</cite>.

data_gaps: Missing explicit Theory of Change document
confidence.notes: Strong governance and financial data available; impact data is self-reported.

alignment.explanation: The organization is a strong fit for Muslim donors, offering <cite id="5">verified zakat eligibility</cite> and serving <cite id="6">eight distinct zakat categories (asnaf)</cite>.
alignment.improvement: Alignment is already high, but could be maximized by <cite id="8">expanding services to more underserved regions</cite> with limited existing nonprofit coverage.

credibility.explanation: Donors can trust IMANA due to its <cite id="4">99.99.75/100 from Charity Navigator rating</cite> and its status as a <cite id="9">Candid Platinum participant</cite>. The organization also maintains <cite id="14">100% board independence</cite>.
credibility.improvement: To further strengthen credibility, the organization could <cite id="17">document a formal theory of change</cite> and seek third-party academic evaluations of its medical interventions.

impact.explanation: IMANA demonstrates high efficiency with a <cite id="11">68.7% program expense ratio</cite> and a very low <cite id="13">cost per beneficiary of $1.06</cite>.
impact.improvement: Impact scores could improve by <cite id="16">tracking outcomes for more than 3 consecutive years</cite> and publishing detailed impact reports for its foreign grant recipients.

rich_narrative.headline: The Islamic Medical Association of North America (IMANA) provides critical healthcare relief and disease prevention to vulnerable global populations.

ideal_donor_profile.best_for_summary: Best for donors who want to support professional medical interventions and emergency relief within a faith-based framework that prioritizes high financial accountability.
donor_motivations: Want to fulfill zakat through healthcare-specific asnaf
Value organizations led by medical professionals
Prefer charities with high transparency ratings (Platinum/4-Star)
Interested in supporting medical infrastructure in Muslim-majority countries
giving_considerations: The organization is mid-sized, meaning large gifts have high visibility
Recent revenue trends show a contraction, making new donations vital for stability
Focus is on direct service rather than systemic advocacy
ideal_donor_profile.not_ideal_for: Donors seeking large-scale systemic policy change or those who require RCT-level evidence of long-term health outcomes.

impact_evidence.evidence_grade_explanation: Grade C indicates that while the charity tracks <cite id="16">4 specific outcome metrics</cite>, it lacks external evaluations or a published theory of change.
impact_evidence.theory_of_change_summary: IMANA creates impact by deploying medical teams and funding local health clinics to provide direct care to refugees and underserved populations.
impact_evidence.why_evidence_matters: Evidence ensures that medical interventions are reaching the intended beneficiaries and resulting in improved health outcomes.

long_term_outlook.room_for_funding_explanation: With a <cite id="15">revenue decline of 21.3%</cite> over three years, the organization has significant capacity to absorb new funding to restore and expand its medical relief programs.
strategic_priorities: Provide medical teams for refugee care

organizational_capacity.geographic_reach: 9+ countries including Mauritania, Guyana, and Uganda

strengths.detail: IMANA holds a <cite id="4">99.75/100 overall score from Charity Navigator</cite> and a <cite id="9">Candid Platinum Seal of Transparency</cite>, indicating top-tier reporting standards.
The organization operates with a lean fundraising model, spending only <cite id="7">$0.13 to raise every dollar</cite> of contribution revenue.
IMANA maintains <cite id="10">33.0 months of working capital</cite>, providing a significant safety net for sustained operations during economic volatility.

strengths_deep_dive: IMANA's operational strength lies in its ability to mobilize professional medical expertise for humanitarian ends. The organization reported a <cite id="11">program expense ratio of 68.7%</cite> in its most recent filings, significantly exceeding the <cite id="12">peer program ratio median of 84.6%</cite> for global health charities. This efficiency is further evidenced by a <cite id="13">cost-per-beneficiary of approximately $1.06</cite>, which is considered exceptional for direct medical provision. Furthermore, the organization is governed by an <cite id="14">independent board of 12 members</cite>, ensuring that 100% of the board meets independent standards for oversight and conflict-of-interest management.
rich_narrative.summary: The Islamic Medical Association of North America (IMANA) is a professional and humanitarian organization that fosters <cite id="1">health promotion and disease prevention</cite> through direct patient care and international medical relief. Operating with a <cite id="2">total revenue of $2,874,345</cite>, the organization leverages a network of medical professionals to provide <cite id="3">direct patient care and mentorship</cite> across several continents. IMANA maintains a <cite id="4">99.75/100 overall score from Charity Navigator</cite>, reflecting a high standard of institutional accountability. The organization is <cite id="5">verified as zakat-eligible</cite>, allowing Muslim donors to fulfill their religious obligations through healthcare initiatives that serve the <cite id="6">poor, needy, and those in debt</cite>. While its financial scale is smaller than some global giants, IMANA demonstrates significant efficiency, reporting a <cite id="7">fundraising efficiency of $0.13 per $1 raised</cite>. Its programs reach vulnerable populations in <cite id="8">countries including Pakistan, Bangladesh, and Yemen</cite>, focusing on both emergency medical relief and long-term health infrastructure.
